# Claude Code Sync Setup Guide - Davide's Personal Setup

Complete setup instructions for syncing Claude Code between your macOS personal laptop and Windows work PC.

## 🔧 Your Repository Setup:
- **Sync Tool Repository**: `https://github.com/davide-f98/claude-sync-project` (corrected version)
- **Data Sync Repository**: `https://github.com/davide-f98/claude-sync` (your Claude Code data)

## ✅ Current Status (macOS - Personal Laptop):
- **Installation**: ✅ COMPLETE - claude-sync installed with corrected paths
- **Configuration**: ✅ COMPLETE - configured to sync to `davide-f98/claude-sync`
- **Sync Level**: ✅ FULL - syncs everything including commands and agents
- **Machine ID**: `523df774`
- **Available Commands**: `/sync-status`, `/sync-pull-full`, `/sync-push-full`, `/sync-full`

## 📋 Next Steps:
1. **Push your current data**: Run `/sync-push-full` to upload your macOS Claude Code data
2. **Install on Windows**: Follow the Windows installation instructions below
3. **Pull on Windows**: Run `/sync-pull-full` on Windows to get your macOS data

## Prerequisites

- **Git installed** on both machines with GitHub access
- **Python 3.6+** available on both systems
- **GitHub account** with ability to create private repositories

## Step 1: Create GitHub Repository

1. Go to [GitHub](https://github.com/new)
2. Create a **PRIVATE** repository named `claude-sync` (or any name you prefer)
3. Don't initialize with README, .gitignore, or license
4. Note the repository URL (e.g., `https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/claude-sync`)

## Step 2: Installation on macOS

### Option A: One-line installation (Full sync) - **YOUR CORRECTED VERSION**
```bash
curl -sSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/davide-f98/claude-sync-project/main/install-full.sh | bash -s -- https://github.com/davide-f98/claude-sync.git full
```

### Option B: One-line installation (Essential sync only) - **YOUR CORRECTED VERSION**
```bash
curl -sSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/davide-f98/claude-sync-project/main/install-full.sh | bash -s -- https://github.com/davide-f98/claude-sync.git essential
```

### Option C: Manual installation - **YOUR CORRECTED VERSION**
```bash
# Download the corrected script
curl -sSL -o ~/claude-sync-extended.py https://raw.githubusercontent.com/davide-f98/claude-sync-project/main/claude-sync-extended.py
chmod +x ~/claude-sync-extended.py

# Setup with your repository
python3 ~/claude-sync-extended.py setup --git-repo https://github.com/davide-f98/claude-sync.git --level full

# Create slash commands directory
mkdir -p ~/.claude/commands

# Download and create slash commands (see install-full.sh for command definitions)
# Or run the full installer to get all commands automatically
```

## Step 3: Installation on Windows

### Option A: PowerShell one-liner (Run as Administrator) - **YOUR CORRECTED VERSION**
```powershell
# Download and run with your repositories
$script = (New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadString('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/davide-f98/claude-sync-project/main/install-windows.ps1')
Invoke-Expression $script -GitRepo "https://github.com/davide-f98/claude-sync.git" -Level "full"
```

### Option B: Manual Windows installation - **YOUR CORRECTED VERSION**
```powershell
# Create directories
New-Item -ItemType Directory -Force -Path "$env:USERPROFILE\.claude\commands"
New-Item -ItemType Directory -Force -Path "$env:USERPROFILE\.claude-sync"

# Download the corrected sync script
Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/davide-f98/claude-sync-project/main/claude-sync-extended.py" -OutFile "$env:USERPROFILE\claude-sync-extended.py"

# Setup with your repository
python3 "$env:USERPROFILE\claude-sync-extended.py" setup --git-repo "https://github.com/davide-f98/claude-sync.git" --level full

# Create slash commands manually (see install-windows.ps1 for definitions)
```

## Step 4: Sync Levels Explained

### Essential Level (Recommended for most users)
Syncs core Claude Code data:
- ✅ CLAUDE.md context files (current directory)
- ✅ Claude configuration (`~/.claude.json`)
- ✅ Global settings (`~/.claude/settings.json`)
- ✅ Local settings (`~/.claude/settings.local.json`)
- ✅ All conversation sessions (`~/.claude/projects/`)
- ✅ Global Claude memory (`~/.claude/CLAUDE.md`)

### Full Level (Power users)
Everything from Essential plus:
- ✅ User commands (`~/.claude/commands/`)
- ✅ User agents (`~/.claude/agents/`)
- ⚠️  Credentials (backed up but not synced for security)

## Step 5: Available Commands

After installation, you have both Claude Code slash commands and terminal commands:

### Claude Code Slash Commands (Inside Claude Code):

| Command | Description | Use Case |
|---------|-------------|----------|
| `/sync-status` | Show sync configuration and status | Check what will be synced |
| `/sync-pull` | Pull essential data from remote | Get updates from other machines |
| `/sync-push` | Push essential data to remote | Upload your current setup |
| `/sync-pull-full` | Pull ALL Claude data | Full sync from other machines |
| `/sync-push-full` | Push ALL Claude data | Upload everything to remote |
| `/sync-full` | Complete bidirectional sync | Two-way sync of all data |

### Terminal Commands (From any terminal/command prompt):

| Command | Description | Use Case |
|---------|-------------|----------|
| `sync-status` | Show sync configuration and status | Check what will be synced |
| `sync-pull` | Pull essential data from remote | Get updates from other machines |
| `sync-push` | Push essential data to remote | Upload your current setup |
| `sync-pull-full` | Pull ALL Claude data | Full sync from other machines |
| `sync-push-full` | Push ALL Claude data | Upload everything to remote |
| `sync-full` | Complete bidirectional sync | Two-way sync of all data |

## Step 6: Initial Setup

### On your primary machine (where you have existing Claude Code data):

1. **Push your data to GitHub:**
   ```
   /sync-push-full
   ```
   This uploads all your current sessions, settings, and configurations.

2. **Verify the sync worked:**
   ```
   /sync-status
   ```

### On your secondary machine:

1. **Pull data from GitHub:**
   ```
   /sync-pull-full
   ```
   This downloads everything from your primary machine.

2. **Verify the sync:**
   ```
   /sync-status
   ```

## Step 7: Terminal Command Access

After installation, sync commands are available from any terminal:

### macOS:
Commands installed in `~/.local/bin/` and added to PATH automatically.
If commands don't work, restart terminal or run:
```bash
export PATH="$HOME/.local/bin:$PATH"
```

### Windows:
Commands installed in `%USERPROFILE%\bin\` and added to PATH automatically.
If commands don't work, restart Command Prompt/PowerShell.

### Usage Examples:
```bash
# Check sync status
sync-status

# Quick sync from anywhere
sync-full

# Push latest changes
sync-push-full

# Pull updates from other machines
sync-pull-full
```

## Step 8: Daily Workflow

### When starting work on a machine:
```bash
# From Claude Code:
/sync-pull-full

# OR from terminal:
sync-pull-full
```

### When finishing work on a machine:
```bash
# From Claude Code:
/sync-push-full

# OR from terminal:
sync-push-full
```

### For automatic two-way sync:
```bash
# From Claude Code:
/sync-full

# OR from terminal:
sync-full
```

## Troubleshooting

### Common Issues

#### 1. "Repository access denied"
- Ensure your GitHub repository is created and you have access
- Check your Git credentials: `git config --global user.name` and `git config --global user.email`
- Try cloning the repository manually: `git clone https://github.com/YOUR_USERNAME/claude-sync.git`

#### 2. "No Git repository configured"
- Run setup again: `python3 ~/claude-sync-extended.py setup --git-repo YOUR_REPO_URL --level full`

#### 3. "Permission denied" errors
- On Windows: Run PowerShell as Administrator
- On macOS: Check file permissions with `ls -la ~/claude-sync-extended.py`

#### 4. Python not found
- **Windows**: Install Python from python.org or Microsoft Store
- **macOS**: Install Python via Homebrew: `brew install python3`

#### 5. Sync conflicts
```bash
# Check what's wrong
/sync-status

# Force clean sync (will lose local changes)
cd ~/.claude-sync/data/repo
git reset --hard origin/main
/sync-pull-full
```

### Manual Recovery

If you need to manually access your synced data:
```bash
cd ~/.claude-sync/data/repo
ls -la  # See all machine data folders
```

Each machine gets its own folder with a unique ID, so you can manually copy files if needed.

## Security Considerations

- ✅ Uses your private GitHub repository
- ✅ Credentials are backed up but not synced
- ✅ All data encrypted in transit via HTTPS
- ✅ Each machine gets unique, anonymous ID
- ⚠️  Don't sync the repository publicly
- ⚠️  Be careful with MCP server configurations containing secrets

## Advanced Usage

### Custom sync frequency
Set up cron jobs (macOS/Linux) or Task Scheduler (Windows) to run sync commands automatically.

### Selective sync
Currently syncs everything at the chosen level. Future versions will support selective sync.

### Team sharing
You can share the repository with team members, but be careful about credentials and personal settings.

## File Locations Reference

### macOS/Linux:
- Config: `~/.claude-sync/config.json`
- Data: `~/.claude-sync/data/`
- Commands: `~/.claude/commands/`
- Claude Config: `~/.claude.json`
- Sessions: `~/.claude/projects/`

### Windows:
- Config: `%USERPROFILE%\.claude-sync\config.json`
- Data: `%USERPROFILE%\.claude-sync\data\`
- Commands: `%USERPROFILE%\.claude\commands\`
- Claude Config: `%USERPROFILE%\.claude.json`
- Sessions: `%USERPROFILE%\.claude\projects\`

## Support

If you encounter issues:
1. Check this troubleshooting guide
2. Run `/sync-status` to diagnose
3. Check the GitHub repository for updates
4. Open an issue on the original repository

Happy syncing! 🚀

file.content:
# Claude Context Sync - Windows PowerShell installer
# Usage: iex ((New-Object System.Net.WebClient).DownloadString('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/shaike1/claude-sync/main/install-windows.ps1'))

param(
    [Parameter(Mandatory=$false)]
    [string]$GitRepo,
    
    [Parameter(Mandatory=$false)]
    [string]$Level = "essential"
)

# Colors for output
$Green = [System.ConsoleColor]::Green
$Blue = [System.ConsoleColor]::Blue
$Yellow = [System.ConsoleColor]::Yellow
$Red = [System.ConsoleColor]::Red

function Write-ColorOutput($ForegroundColor, $Message) {
    $originalColor = $Host.UI.RawUI.ForegroundColor
    $Host.UI.RawUI.ForegroundColor = $ForegroundColor
    Write-Output $Message
    $Host.UI.RawUI.ForegroundColor = $originalColor
}

Write-ColorOutput $Blue "🚀 Claude Context Sync Extended - Windows Installer"
Write-Output "=================================================="

# Get GitHub repo from parameter or prompt
if (-not $GitRepo) {
    Write-ColorOutput $Blue "Enter your GitHub repository URL:"
    $GitRepo = Read-Host
}

# Validate repo URL
if ($GitRepo -notmatch '^https://github\.com/[^/]+/[^/]+(\.git)?$') {
    Write-ColorOutput $Red "❌ Invalid GitHub repository URL"
    exit 1
}

# Ensure .git extension
if ($GitRepo -notmatch '\.git$') {
    $GitRepo += ".git"
}

# Validate sync level
if ($Level -notin @("essential", "full")) {
    Write-ColorOutput $Yellow "⚠ Invalid sync level '$Level', using 'essential'"
    $Level = "essential"
}

Write-ColorOutput $Blue "📦 Installing Claude Context Sync Extended..."
Write-Output "Repository: $GitRepo"
Write-Output "Sync Level: $Level"

# Create directories
$claudeDir = Join-Path $env:USERPROFILE ".claude"
$commandsDir = Join-Path $claudeDir "commands"
$syncDir = Join-Path $env:USERPROFILE ".claude-sync"

New-Item -ItemType Directory -Force -Path $commandsDir | Out-Null
New-Item -ItemType Directory -Force -Path $syncDir | Out-Null

# Download the extended sync script
Write-Output "📥 Downloading claude-sync-extended.py..."
$syncScriptPath = Join-Path $env:USERPROFILE "claude-sync-extended.py"
try {
    Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/shaike1/claude-sync/main/claude-sync-extended.py" -OutFile $syncScriptPath
} catch {
    Write-ColorOutput $Red "❌ Failed to download sync script: $_"
    exit 1
}

# Create enhanced slash commands
Write-Output "📝 Creating extended slash commands..."

# /sync-full-setup
@"
Configure Claude Context Sync Extended with full data synchronization.

``````bash
if [ -z "`$1" ]; then
    echo "Usage: /sync-full-setup <github-repo-url> [essential|full]"
    echo "Sync levels:"
    echo "  essential - CLAUDE.md, settings, sessions, MCP configs"
    echo "  full      - Everything including commands and agents"
    exit 1
fi

LEVEL="`${2:-essential}"
python3 ~/claude-sync-extended.py setup --git-repo "`$1" --level "`$LEVEL"
echo "✅ Extended sync configured!"
echo "📊 Run /sync-status to see what will be synced"
``````
"@ | Out-File -FilePath (Join-Path $commandsDir "sync-full-setup.md") -Encoding utf8

# /sync-status
@"
Show detailed Claude Context Sync status and what will be synced.

``````bash
python3 ~/claude-sync-extended.py status
``````
"@ | Out-File -FilePath (Join-Path $commandsDir "sync-status.md") -Encoding utf8

# /sync-pull-full
@"
Pull ALL Claude data from remote repository (sessions, settings, MCP configs).

``````bash
cd ~
echo "🔄 Pulling full Claude data from remote..."
python3 ~/claude-sync-extended.py pull
echo "✅ Full data sync completed!"
echo "📋 Your sessions, settings, and MCP configs are now synchronized"
``````
"@ | Out-File -FilePath (Join-Path $commandsDir "sync-pull-full.md") -Encoding utf8

# /sync-push-full
@"
Push ALL Claude data to remote repository for other PCs to access.

``````bash
cd ~
echo "📤 Pushing full Claude data to remote..."
python3 ~/claude-sync-extended.py push
echo "✅ All data pushed to remote!"
echo "🔗 Other PCs can now pull your sessions, settings, and configurations"
``````
"@ | Out-File -FilePath (Join-Path $commandsDir "sync-push-full.md") -Encoding utf8

# /sync-full
@"
Perform complete bidirectional sync of ALL Claude data.

``````bash
cd ~
echo "🔄 Performing full Claude data sync..."
python3 ~/claude-sync-extended.py sync
echo "✅ Complete sync finished!"
echo ""
echo "📊 Synced data includes:"
echo "  • 💬 All conversation sessions"
echo "  • ⚙️  Claude settings and preferences" 
echo "  • 🔌 MCP server configurations"
echo "  • 📝 Project-specific contexts"
echo "  • 🗂️  User commands and agents"
``````
"@ | Out-File -FilePath (Join-Path $commandsDir "sync-full.md") -Encoding utf8

# Keep the simple commands too
@"
Pull Claude context from remote (essential data only).

``````bash
cd ~
python3 ~/claude-sync-extended.py pull
echo "✅ Essential data synchronized"
``````
"@ | Out-File -FilePath (Join-Path $commandsDir "sync-pull.md") -Encoding utf8

@"
Push Claude context to remote (essential data only).

``````bash
cd ~
python3 ~/claude-sync-extended.py push
echo "✅ Essential data pushed"
``````
"@ | Out-File -FilePath (Join-Path $commandsDir "sync-push.md") -Encoding utf8

# Create terminal commands
Write-Output "📟 Creating terminal commands..."
$binDir = Join-Path $env:USERPROFILE "bin"
New-Item -ItemType Directory -Force -Path $binDir | Out-Null

# Download and create batch files for terminal commands
$commands = @("sync-status", "sync-pull", "sync-push", "sync-pull-full", "sync-push-full", "sync-full")
foreach ($cmd in $commands) {
    try {
        Invoke-WebRequest -Uri "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/davide-f98/claude-sync-project/main/bin/$cmd.bat" -OutFile (Join-Path $binDir "$cmd.bat")
    } catch {
        Write-ColorOutput $Yellow "⚠ Warning: Could not download $cmd.bat"
    }
}

# Add to PATH if needed
$userPath = [Environment]::GetEnvironmentVariable("PATH", "User")
if ($userPath -notlike "*$binDir*") {
    $newPath = "$binDir;$userPath"
    [Environment]::SetEnvironmentVariable("PATH", $newPath, "User")
    Write-ColorOutput $Yellow "ℹ️  Added $binDir to PATH. Restart terminal to use commands."
}

# Setup with provided repo and level
Write-ColorOutput $Blue "`n⚙️  Configuring with repository and sync level..."
try {
    & python3 $syncScriptPath setup --git-repo $GitRepo --level $Level
} catch {
    Write-ColorOutput $Red "❌ Failed to configure sync: $_"
    exit 1
}

# Show status
Write-ColorOutput $Blue "`n📊 Current sync configuration:"
& python3 $syncScriptPath status

# Try initial sync
Write-ColorOutput $Blue "`n🔄 Attempting initial sync..."
try {
    & python3 $syncScriptPath push 2>$null
    Write-ColorOutput $Green "✅ Initial sync successful"
} catch {
    Write-ColorOutput $Yellow "ℹ️  Initial sync skipped (repository might be empty)"
}

Write-ColorOutput $Green "`n✨ Claude Context Sync Extended installed!"
Write-ColorOutput $Blue "`n📋 Available commands:"
Write-Output "Claude Code slash commands:"
Write-Output "  /sync-pull          - Pull context and basic settings"
Write-Output "  /sync-push          - Push context and basic settings"
Write-Output "  /sync-pull-full     - Pull ALL Claude data (sessions, MCP, etc.)"
Write-Output "  /sync-push-full     - Push ALL Claude data"
Write-Output "  /sync-full          - Complete bidirectional sync"
Write-Output "  /sync-status        - Show detailed sync status"
Write-Output ""
Write-Output "Terminal commands (from any directory):"
Write-Output "  sync-pull           - Pull context and basic settings"
Write-Output "  sync-push           - Push context and basic settings"
Write-Output "  sync-pull-full      - Pull ALL Claude data"
Write-Output "  sync-push-full      - Push ALL Claude data"
Write-Output "  sync-full           - Complete bidirectional sync"
Write-Output "  sync-status         - Show detailed sync status"

Write-ColorOutput $Blue "`n🎯 What gets synced at '$Level' level:"

if ($Level -eq "essential") {
    Write-Output "  ✅ CLAUDE.md context files"
    Write-Output "  ✅ Claude settings (~/.claude.json)"
    Write-Output "  ✅ Conversation sessions"
    Write-Output "  ✅ MCP server configurations"
    Write-Output "  ✅ Global Claude memory"
} else {
    Write-Output "  ✅ Everything from 'essential' plus:"
    Write-Output "  ✅ User commands and agents"
    Write-Output "  ✅ All user preferences"
}

Write-ColorOutput $Blue "`n🚀 Quick start:"
Write-Output "1. Use /sync-push-full to upload your current Claude setup"
Write-Output "2. On other PCs, install with same repo and run /sync-pull-full"
Write-Output "3. All your sessions, settings, and configs will be synchronized!"
Write-ColorOutput $Green "`nHappy syncing! 🎉"

Yes, sir. I have successfully analyzed the new additions to the repository and installed the claude-sync tool on your Windows machine.

The new additions include:
- **Windows batch scripts**: A complete set of `.bat` files for terminal-based sync commands
- **Updated installation scripts**: Enhanced PowerShell and bash installers with better Windows compatibility
- **Terminal command support**: Commands like `sync-status`, `sync-full`, `sync-pull-full`, etc. now work from any terminal

The sync tool is now configured with:
- Repository: `https://github.com/davide-f98/claude-sync.git`
- Sync level: `full`
- Machine ID: `3c6a6b55`

You can now use the sync commands from both Claude Code (slash commands like `/sync-full`) and from any terminal (commands like `sync-full`).

1→Start all your messages with "Yes, sir".

     3→Use uv commands to manage dependencies and run python scripts (e.g. uv init, uv add pandas, uv sync, uv run main.py).
     4→
     5→Use only ASCII characters.
     6→Never use UNICODE characters. 
     7→Never use "try...except" when coding in python.
     8→Make the code simple and straightforward so that its logic is easy to understand for non-coder people too.
     9→Always commit after you write a new function or you fix a bug.
    10→Commit messages should be simple and straightforward.
    11→Always keep a tracklist with the current progress of the project in its PLAN.md file so that a new session of Claude Code can read it and instantly gather informations about the project.
    12→In said PLAN.md file make sure to write the fixes you applied too.
    13→
    14→# Using Gemini CLI for Large Codebase Analysis
    15→
    16→When analyzing large codebases or multiple files that might exceed context limits, use the Gemini CLI with its massive
    17→context window. Use `gemini -p` to leverage Google Gemini's large context capacity.
    18→
    19→## File and Directory Inclusion Syntax
    20→
    21→Use the `@` syntax to include files and directories in your Gemini prompts. The paths should be relative to WHERE you run the
    22→  gemini command:
    23→
    24→### Examples:
    25→
    26→**Single file analysis:**
    27→gemini -p "@src/main.py Explain this file's purpose and structure"
    28→
    29→Multiple files:
    30→gemini -p "@package.json @src/index.js Analyze the dependencies used in the code"
    31→
    32→Entire directory:
    33→gemini -p "@src/ Summarize the architecture of this codebase"
    34→
    35→Multiple directories:
    36→gemini -p "@src/ @tests/ Analyze test coverage for the source code"
    37→
    38→Current directory and subdirectories:
    39→gemini -p "@./ Give me an overview of this entire project"
    40→
    41→# Or use --all_files flag:
    42→gemini --all_files -p "Analyze the project structure and dependencies"
    43→
    44→Implementation Verification Examples
    45→
    46→Check if a feature is implemented:
    47→gemini -p "@src/ @lib/ Has dark mode been implemented in this codebase? Show me the relevant files and functions"
    48→
    49→Verify authentication implementation:
    50→gemini -p "@src/ @middleware/ Is JWT authentication implemented? List all auth-related endpoints and middleware"
    51→
    52→Check for specific patterns:
    53→gemini -p "@src/ Are there any React hooks that handle WebSocket connections? List them with file paths"
    54→
    55→Verify error handling:
    56→gemini -p "@src/ @api/ Is proper error handling implemented for all API endpoints? Show examples of try-catch blocks"
    57→
    58→Check for rate limiting:
    59→gemini -p "@backend/ @middleware/ Is rate limiting implemented for the API? Show the implementation details"
    60→

# Using Gemini CLI for Large Codebase Analysis

When analyzing large codebases or multiple files that might exceed context limits, use the Gemini CLI with its massive
context window. Use `gemini -p` to leverage Google Gemini's large context capacity.

## File and Directory Inclusion Syntax

Use the `@` syntax to include files and directories in your Gemini prompts. The paths should be relative to WHERE you run the
  gemini command:

### Examples:

**Single file analysis:**
gemini -p "@src/main.py Explain this file's purpose and structure"

Multiple files:
gemini -p "@package.json @src/index.js Analyze the dependencies used in the code"

Entire directory:
gemini -p "@src/ Summarize the architecture of this codebase"

Multiple directories:
gemini -p "@src/ @tests/ Analyze test coverage for the source code"

Current directory and subdirectories:
gemini -p "@./ Give me an overview of this entire project"

# Or use --all_files flag:
gemini --all_files -p "Analyze the project structure and dependencies"

Implementation Verification Examples

Check if a feature is implemented:
gemini -p "@src/ @lib/ Has dark mode been implemented in this codebase? Show me the relevant files and functions"

Verify authentication implementation:
gemini -p "@src/ @middleware/ Is JWT authentication implemented? List all auth-related endpoints and middleware"

Check for specific patterns:
gemini -p "@src/ Are there any React hooks that handle WebSocket connections? List them with file paths"

Verify error handling:
gemini -p "@src/ @api/ Is proper error handling implemented for all API endpoints? Show examples of try-catch blocks"

Check for rate limiting:
gemini -p "@backend/ @middleware/ Is rate limiting implemented for the API? Show the implementation details"

Verify caching strategy:
gemini -p "@src/ @lib/ @services/ Is Redis caching implemented? List all cache-related functions and their usage"

Check for specific security measures:
gemini -p "@src/ @api/ Are SQL injection protections implemented? Show how user inputs are sanitized"

Verify test coverage for features:
gemini -p "@src/payment/ @tests/ Is the payment processing module fully tested? List all test cases"

When to Use Gemini CLI

Use gemini -p when:
- Analyzing entire codebases or large directories
- Comparing multiple large files
- Need to understand project-wide patterns or architecture
- Current context window is insufficient for the task
- Working with files totaling more than 100KB
- Verifying if specific features, patterns, or security measures are implemented
- Checking for the presence of certain coding patterns across the entire codebase

Important Notes

- Paths in @ syntax are relative to your current working directory when invoking gemini
- The CLI will include file contents directly in the context
- No need for --yolo flag for read-only analysis
- Gemini's context window can handle entire codebases that would overflow Claude's context
- When checking implementations, be specific about what you're looking for to get accurate results

# Using Gemini CLI for Large Codebase Analysis

When analyzing large codebases or multiple files that might exceed context limits, use the Gemini CLI with its massive
context window. Use `gemini -p` to leverage Google Gemini's large context capacity.

## File and Directory Inclusion Syntax

Use the `@` syntax to include files and directories in your Gemini prompts. The paths should be relative to WHERE you run the
  gemini command:

### Examples:

**Single file analysis:**
gemini -p "@src/main.py Explain this file's purpose and structure"

Multiple files:
gemini -p "@package.json @src/index.js Analyze the dependencies used in the code"

Entire directory:
gemini -p "@src/ Summarize the architecture of this codebase"

Multiple directories:
gemini -p "@src/ @tests/ Analyze test coverage for the source code"

Current directory and subdirectories:
gemini -p "@./ Give me an overview of this entire project"

# Or use --all_files flag:
gemini --all_files -p "Analyze the project structure and dependencies"

Implementation Verification Examples

Check if a feature is implemented:
gemini -p "@src/ @lib/ Has dark mode been implemented in this codebase? Show me the relevant files and functions"

Verify authentication implementation:
gemini -p "@src/ @middleware/ Is JWT authentication implemented? List all auth-related endpoints and middleware"

Check for specific patterns:
gemini -p "@src/ Are there any React hooks that handle WebSocket connections? List them with file paths"

Verify error handling:
gemini -p "@src/ @api/ Is proper error handling implemented for all API endpoints? Show examples of try-catch blocks"

Check for rate limiting:
gemini -p "@backend/ @middleware/ Is rate limiting implemented for the API? Show the implementation details"

Verify caching strategy:
gemini -p "@src/ @lib/ @services/ Is Redis caching implemented? List all cache-related functions and their usage"

Check for specific security measures:
gemini -p "@src/ @api/ Are SQL injection protections implemented? Show how user inputs are sanitized"

Verify test coverage for features:
gemini -p "@src/payment/ @tests/ Is the payment processing module fully tested? List all test cases"

When to Use Gemini CLI

Use gemini -p when:
- Analyzing entire codebases or large directories
- Comparing multiple large files
- Need to understand project-wide patterns or architecture
- Current context window is insufficient for the task
- Working with files totaling more than 100KB
- Verifying if specific features, patterns, or security measures are implemented
- Checking for the presence of certain coding patterns across the entire codebase

Important Notes

- Paths in @ syntax are relative to your current working directory when invoking gemini
- The CLI will include file contents directly in the context
- No need for --yolo flag for read-only analysis
- Gemini's context window can handle entire codebases that would overflow Claude's context
- When checking implementations, be specific about what you're looking for to get accurate results

Yes, sir. I have added a much stronger and more explicit ASCII-ONLY policy to your CLAUDE.md file. The new rules include:

**✅ Added Stronger ASCII-ONLY Policy:**
- **Clear title:** "STRICT ASCII-ONLY POLICY" at the top
- **Explicit forbidden characters:** Lists Unicode, emojis, symbols, and special characters
- **Comprehensive scope:** Applies to ALL code, comments, strings, output messages, documentation, and any generated text
- **Specific character range:** Only ASCII range 32-126 allowed
- **Pre-display check:** Requires checking all generated text before showing it
- **ASCII equivalents guidance:** Shows examples like using "done" instead of checkmark emoji
- **Explicit forbidden list:** Shows exactly which punctuation is allowed

The key improvement is making the rule much more explicit about what is forbidden and where the rule applies. The new rule specifically mentions "output messages" and "any text generated or displayed" which should prevent Unicode characters from appearing in sync command outputs and other messages.
